perturbation.original_text: 2.1 Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, WPD hereby agrees to use its commercially reasonable efforts in good faith to take, or cause to be taken, all actions, and to do or cause to be done, all things necessary, proper or desirable or advisable under applicable laws to develop and commercialize the Development Products, with a goal of eventual approval of Development Products in the Development Territory. In exchange for the payment by WPD of the Development Fee to CNS, CNS hereby agrees to pay WPD the following payments: (i) within thirty Business Days from the date of this Agreement, CNS will make an upfront payment of $225,000 to WPD; and (ii) within thirty days of the verified achievement of the Phase II Milestone, (such verification shall be conducted by an independent third party mutually acceptable to the parties hereto), CNS will make a payment of $775,000 to WPD.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.1 Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, WPD hereby agrees to use its commercially reasonable efforts in good faith to take, or cause to be taken, all actions, and to do or cause to be done, all things necessary, proper or desirable or advisable under applicable laws to develop and commercialize the Development Products, with a goal of eventual approval of Development Products in the Development Territory. In exchange for the payment by WPD of the Development Fee to CNS, CNS hereby agrees to pay WPD the following payments: (i) within ninety Business Days from the date of this Agreement, CNS will make an upfront payment of $225,000 to WPD; and (ii) within sixty days of the verified achievement of the Phase II Milestone, (such verification shall be conducted by an independent third party mutually acceptable to the parties hereto), CNS will make a payment of $775,000 to WPD.
perturbation.explanation: The modification extends the payment deadlines, potentially conflicting with prompt payment laws or regulations that require payments to be made within a reasonable and shorter timeframe in some jurisdictions. This delay could also constitute a breach of contract if it is deemed unreasonably long and causes financial harm to WPD. Though Texas does not explicitly have prompt payment laws for private contracts, extending the payment terms this significantly without proper justification could be deemed unreasonable and a breach of good faith.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of implied duty of good faith and fair dealing; possible conflict with prompt payment principles.

perturbation.original_text: 2.3 The first Development Fees payment shall be due forty-five days after the end of the Calendar Quarter in which the first Sale of a Development Product took place. Thereafter, WPD shall furnish to CNS Development Fees no later than forty-five days after the end of each Calendar Quarter for the Sale of Development Products through the end of such Calendar Quarter and shall further furnish CNS with a written statement setting forth an accounting showing the calculation of the Development Fees.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.3 The first Development Fees payment shall be due one hundred and twenty days after the end of the Calendar Quarter in which the first Sale of a Development Product took place. Thereafter, WPD shall furnish to CNS Development Fees no later than one hundred and twenty days after the end of each Calendar Quarter for the Sale of Development Products through the end of such Calendar Quarter and shall further furnish CNS with a written statement setting forth an accounting showing the calculation of the Development Fees.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the payment deadline to 120 days after the end of the calendar quarter is unreasonable and exceeds commonly accepted payment terms. This could lead to cash flow issues for CNS and contradicts the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing inherent in the contract. While Texas law doesn't specify mandatory payment deadlines for all commercial contracts, excessively long delays could still be challenged as breaches of contract or violations of good faith principles.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential breach of implied duty of good faith and fair dealing. Conflict with reasonable business practices.

perturbation.original_text: 5.1 During the term of this Agreement and for a period of five (5) years thereafter, the Parties each agree that Confidential Information of the disclosing party, which is disclosed to the recipient party pursuant to this Agreement: (i) shall be received and held in strict confidence, (ii) shall be used only for the purposes of this Agreement, and (iii) will not be disclosed by the recipient party (except as required by law, court order or regulation), its agents or employees without the prior written consent of the disclosing party, except to the extent that the recipient party can establish by competent written proof that particular Confidential Information: (i) was in the public domain at the time of disclosure to the recipient party; or later became part of the public domain through no act or omission of the recipient party, its employees, agents, successors or assigns; or (ii) was lawfully disclosed to the recipient party by a third party having the right to disclose it to the recipient party; or (iii) was already known by the recipient party at the time of disclosure; or (iv) was independently developed by the recipient party without use of the disclosing party's Confidential Information; or (iv) is required by law, court order or regulation to be disclosed, provided that the recipient party so obligated to disclose the Confidential Information shall promptly notify the disclosing party of such requirement and provide the disclosing party an opportunity to challenge or limit the disclosure requirement and to seek confidential treatment or protection order, and that the Confidential Information so disclosed shall remain otherwise subject to the confidentiality and non-use obligations set forth above in this section. Particular Confidential Information shall not be deemed to come under any of the above exceptions merely because it is embraced by more general information that is or becomes subject to any of the above exceptions.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.1 During the term of this Agreement and for a period of one (1) year thereafter, the Parties each agree that Confidential Information of the disclosing party, which is disclosed to the recipient party pursuant to this Agreement: (i) shall be received and held in strict confidence, (ii) shall be used only for the purposes of this Agreement, and (iii) will not be disclosed by the recipient party (except as required by law, court order or regulation), its agents or employees without the prior written consent of the disclosing party, except to the extent that the recipient party can establish by competent written proof that particular Confidential Information: (i) was in the public domain at the time of disclosure to the recipient party; or later became part of the public domain through no act or omission of the recipient party, its employees, agents, successors or assigns; or (ii) was lawfully disclosed to the recipient party by a third party having the right to disclose it to the recipient party; or (iii) was already known by the recipient party at the time of disclosure; or (iv) was independently developed by the recipient party without use of the disclosing party's Confidential Information; or (iv) is required by law, court order or regulation to be disclosed, provided that the recipient party so obligated to disclose the Confidential Information shall promptly notify the disclosing party of such requirement and provide the disclosing party an opportunity to challenge or limit the disclosure requirement and to seek confidential treatment or protection order, and that the Confidential Information so disclosed shall remain otherwise subject to the confidentiality and non-use obligations set forth above in this section. Particular Confidential Information shall not be deemed to come under any of the above exceptions merely because it is embraced by more general information that is or becomes subject to any of the above exceptions.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period to one year might be deemed unreasonable and insufficient to protect trade secrets and other confidential business information. Texas law recognizes and protects trade secrets, and a one-year period may not be adequate for information with a longer commercial lifespan, potentially violating the Texas Uniform Trade Secrets Act (TUTSA) if the information qualifies as a trade secret and the shorter timeframe does not provide adequate protection.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of Texas Uniform Trade Secrets Act (TUTSA) if the shortened timeframe inadequately protects trade secrets.
